title: 1960s Music Legends
description: From the British Invasion to Woodstock â€” how well do you remember the sounds that defined the Sixties?

questions.question: Which Beatles album, released in 1967, is often called the greatest rock album ever made?
options: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
questions.explanation: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band was a groundbreaking concept album that spent 27 weeks at number one in the UK and 15 weeks at number one in the US.

questions.question: What Motown group sang 'My Girl' in 1964?
questions.explanation: The Temptations took 'My Girl' to number one on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1965. It was written and produced by Smokey Robinson and Ronald White.

questions.question: Which legendary music festival took place on a dairy farm in Bethel, New York, in August 1969?
questions.explanation: Woodstock attracted over 400,000 people for three days of peace and music, featuring acts like Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, and The Who.

questions.question: What was the Rolling Stones' first US number-one hit single?
questions.explanation: (I Can't Get No) Satisfaction reached number one in 1965 and became the song that made the Rolling Stones international superstars.

questions.question: Which folk singer wrote and performed 'Blowin' in the Wind'?
questions.explanation: Bob Dylan wrote 'Blowin' in the Wind' in 1962. It became an anthem of the civil rights and anti-war movements of the 1960s.

questions.question: What city was home to the Motown record label?
questions.explanation: Berry Gordy Jr. founded Motown Records in Detroit in 1959. The name 'Motown' is short for 'Motor Town,' Detroit's nickname for its auto industry.

questions.question: Which Beatles song was the first to hit number one in the United States in 1964?
options: I Want to Hold Your Hand
questions.explanation: I Want to Hold Your Hand reached number one on February 1, 1964, launching Beatlemania in America and the entire British Invasion.

questions.question: Which Supremes hit begins with the lyrics 'Stop! In the name of love'?
options: Stop! In the Name of Love
questions.explanation: Stop! In the Name of Love was the Supremes' fourth consecutive number-one hit in 1965. Diana Ross's iconic hand-out gesture became legendary.

questions.question: Which guitarist famously played 'The Star-Spangled Banner' at Woodstock?
questions.explanation: Jimi Hendrix closed out Woodstock on Monday morning, August 18, 1969, with a legendary electric guitar rendition of the national anthem.

questions.question: What was the Beach Boys' 1966 album that rivaled Sgt. Pepper's in musical innovation?
questions.explanation: Pet Sounds, masterminded by Brian Wilson, used unconventional instruments and complex arrangements. Paul McCartney has called it his favorite album of all time.

questions.question: Which singer, known as 'The Queen of Soul,' released 'Respect' in 1967?
questions.explanation: Aretha Franklin's version of 'Respect' (originally by Otis Redding) became a feminist and civil rights anthem and earned her two Grammy Awards.

questions.question: What 1967 event in San Francisco is considered the start of the 'Summer of Love'?
questions.explanation: The Human Be-In, held in Golden Gate Park on January 14, 1967, drew 20,000-30,000 people and set the stage for the Summer of Love that followed.

questions.question: Which Simon & Garfunkel song was featured on the soundtrack of 'The Graduate' (1967)?
questions.explanation: Mrs. Robinson was written specifically for the film and became Simon & Garfunkel's first and only number-one single on the Billboard Hot 100.

questions.question: Which musician died in a 1967 plane crash, cutting short a career that included hits like '(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay'?
questions.explanation: Otis Redding died on December 10, 1967. '(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay' was released posthumously in 1968 and became his biggest hit, reaching number one.

questions.question: What was the name of the concert venue in San Francisco that became the epicenter of psychedelic rock?
questions.explanation: The Fillmore, managed by legendary promoter Bill Graham, hosted Jefferson Airplane, the Grateful Dead, Jimi Hendrix, and virtually every major 1960s rock act.
